moves.1. e4 c5: E4 my favorite opening move. c5 attacks d4 & Nf3 protects
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6: Nc6 adding more pressure to d4. Not too worried about that at this time so I will develop Bc4 aiming at f7
moves.3. Bc4 e6: e6 opens diagonals for the Q & B. I think it's best to castle now.
moves.4. O-O Bd6: Bd6 aims at h2 protected by K & N. It is time to get back to protect d4 with c3 keeping the N at bay
moves.5. c3 h6: Not too sure why h6 and not developing the N preparing for castling
moves.6. d4: With 3 pieces covering d4 against 2 pieces it is a good time to play d4 opening the c1 h6 diagonal
moves.6... Nf6 7. d5: Nf6 attacks e4, but d5 pushes the N backwards. ed is met with ed and opens the e file
moves.7... exd5 8. exd5 Ne7 9. Nbd2: With black reversing his N I develop mine Nd2
moves.9... a6: a6 preparing to drive the B away. Not in any danger, I move Re1 to controls the e file.
moves.10. Re1 O-O 11. Ne4: Black castles and Ne4 attacks the B & N. Not wanting to lose the Bishop or N x N opening the King's defense, Black's N x N and R takes N
moves.11... Nxe4 12. Rxe4 b5: b5 attacks the B which reverses to b3
moves.13. Bb3 c4: c4 joins the attack and Bishop settles on c2
moves.14. Bc2 Ng6: Ng6 clears the file for a fight so I strengthen the rear with Re1
moves.15. Re1 Ne5: Ne5 is a mistake, it loses a piece to White and maybe the game also. N xN
moves.16. Nxe5 Qc7: Qc7 doubles the attack on h2 hence N retreats to f3 to protect h2
moves.17. Nf3 Bb7 18. Be4: Bb7 eyes the p at d5 so the Bishop protects at e4
moves.18... f5 19. Bc2: f5 forces the Bishop to c2
moves.19... Rf6 20. Be3: Not too sure of black's plan with the Rf6, I finally develop the Bishop at e3
moves.20... f4: The f4 attack on the Bishop could be another mistake, it blocks the double attack on h2. the Bishop then attacks the R at f6 by going to d4.
moves.21. Bd4 Rf7: The R retreats leaving Pawn at d5 unprotected and having control of e5 decided to trade Bishops
moves.22. Be5 Bxe5 23. Rxe5: B x B R x B instead of N x B keeping P fixed at f4
moves.23... Qc5: Qc5 focus on f2 could have driven the Q with d6 but have to protect  Nf3 so B is added to defend d5
moves.24. Be4 Raf8 25. d6: With Rooks doubled protecting f4 I decided to attack Q with R and B with B pushing p d6
moves.25... Qc8 26. Bxb7 Qxb7: Q retreats to c8  B X B got rid of the attacker of Nf3
moves.27. Qe2 Qb8: Qe2 makes room for rear R move & supports Re5
moves.28... Rf7f6 29. Red5: Rf6 double attack d6 & Re5 to d5 secures d6
moves.29... Re8 30. Qc2: Re8 attacks Q and is moved to control b1-h7 diagonal on c2
moves.30... Rfe6 31. h3: Rf6-e6 doubles on the e file preparing to attack Q. It seems I need an escape for the K with h3
moves.31... Re6e2 32. Rd1d2: Re2 is met with Rd1- d2
moves.33. Qd1: R blocks diagonal Q is on so Qd1guards Nf3 & falls behind the Rook pair
moves.33... Re8e6: Not sure what Re8 - e6 can do but with a piece up it seems a good time to begin trading pieces - Rd4
moves.34... Qb7: Qb2 double protect e4 but as I said it's trading time R x R Q x R
moves.37... Rg6: Rg6 is met with Rg4 for the trade.
moves.38. Rg4 Re6 39. Qd4: Re6 avoids the trade & Qd4 threatens checkmate
moves.39... g5 40. h4: g5 blocks checkmate & h4 is played to weaken g5
moves.40... Rg6: Rg6 is played to support g5 but is driven away with h5
moves.42. Nh4 Qc8 43. Ng6 Qe8: With the pawn pinned Q e8 doubles for attack on K. Ng6 is brought forward in the attack
moves.44. Ne7+: Ne7 + Kh7 Qd5 prepares check K with Qf5
moves.44... Kh7 45. Qd5 Qf7: Qf7 can be met with Qf5 forcing the Q exchange but prefer pinning Rook with Re4
moves.46. Re4 Qf6: Qf6 R x R continues the exchange
moves.47. Rxe6: If Q x R    Q x Q and pd7 head for promotion.
moves.48... Qf7: Qf7 trying to defend the K  Qe4+
moves.49. Qe4+: The K has two squares to go now. If Kg7 then  Qg6+ Q x Q    N x Q
